awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Causes of Natural Variation in Protein Expression
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand how the genetic material of a cell, its DNA, controls the amount of protein each cell produces, how a cell's environment stimulates it to ramp protein production up or down, and how this response differs between individuals. To function, an organism copies specific genetic information from genes in its DNA to molecules called RNA and then uses that RNA as templates to make proteins. Proteins are the molecular machines that carry out the work of cells and give cells their identities. It is not clear what causes the amount of protein that cells make to differ between individuals. It is known that this can be caused by differences in how much RNA is made. However, individuals may differ in how fast they make protein from the same amount of RNA and also how quickly they recycle protein when it gets old. The research will measure RNA and protein levels in two different strains of budding yeast as they respond to mating pheromone. It will involve both broad surveys of many proteins and detailed measurements of a targeted set. While engaging in this research, students at a primarily undergraduate institution and a postdoctoral fellow will gain interdisciplinary training in the emerging field of evolutionary systems biology. Students from a junior high school will also be engaged in scientific discovery; they will collect wild yeasts from the air and from tree bark and identify their relationships to each other in the fungal tree of life, fulfilling the requirements of the Next Generation Science Standards recently adopted by California and Washington.


Specifically, the project seeks to systematically characterize the causes of divergence in protein expression temporal dynamics using a unique combination of high-throughput phenotyping, modeling, cellular resolution quantitative trait mapping, and targeted functional analysis. The mating pheromone response network of the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae will be used as a model system. The research will identify the contribution of variation in mRNA levels, protein production rates, and protein degradation rates to protein levels. Applying this approach to a network of genes will elucidate the general trends in how protein expression variation arises. Identifying the causal polymorphisms underlying protein expression variation will point to the molecular mechanisms for such variation. These project outcomes will have far reaching effects in the fields of evolutionary genetics and systems biology.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit
Proteins are the molecular scaffolds and engines that do the work of cells and differences in the abundance of specific proteins between individuals can cause medically and ecologically important traits to vary in a population. Differences in protein abundance can arise from genetic differences in the DNA of cells and from differences in the environment of cells. These influences can act on the rate of any of the four major steps in protein metabolism: (1) rate of messenger RNA (mRNA) production from genes in DNA, (2) rate of decay of old mRNA, (3) rate of protein production from mRNA, and (4) rate of decay of old protein. Because of technical limitations for measuring protein abundances, most of what we know about how genetic variation and environmental variation influence protein metabolism comes from studies of mRNA abundances, which excludes influences on protein production from mRNA and protein decay.
The goal of this project was to focus on the factors that cause protein abundances to differ between individuals. Toward this goal, in our first aim, we followed the abundance of mRNA and protein for thousands of genes in two individuals (isolates) from the budding yeast population as the environment shifted from normal growth media to media containing a mating pheromone. Focusing on the differences between the isolates, we identified genes with protein-level differences during pheromone response that did not match their mRNA-level differences. These genes were presumed to have altered rates of protein production from mRNA and/or protein decay. We noted that these were also significantly shorter than a typical gene. Future work will attempt to understand this curious observation.
In our second aim, we added fluorescent tags onto these genes in both isolates and confirmed that their protein abundances were indeed different between isolates during pheromone response. We also swapped the DNA of each gene between the isolates and tested for the influence of DNA differences in the gene, DNA differences elsewhere in the genome, time after pheromone treatment, and the interaction of these factors and found that many genes have complex interacting influences from all three factors. Characterizing this complexity helps explain why it has been difficult to identify the genetic causes of common diseases in humans.
In our third aim, we used a powerful genetic mapping technique to identify the locations in the genome of DNA differences that influence protein abundances for each gene in our study. We mapped hundreds of locations in the genome that together form a large genetic network acting on protein abundances during pheromone response. Future work will pinpoint which DNA differences within these genomic locations are responsible and in doing so we hope to refine our understanding of their molecular mechanisms.
In our fourth aim, we tested how DNA changes within a gene impact how much protein the gene makes. The two mechanisms we investigated were codon bias and mRNA folding strength. Codons are triplets of nucleotides (A, C, G, or U) in RNA and are how the genetic code is read and translated from mRNA to protein. There are 64 possible codons but only 20 amino acids they code for and thus there are multiple codons that code for each amino acid. The machinery matches some codons well (high bias) and other codons poorly (low bias). mRNA are single stranded molecules that fold back on themselves to form stable structures. We found that yeast isolates with higher bias codons and more stable mRNA structures for a gene tend to make more of that protein from the pool of mRNA in the cell. Furthermore, we found that codon bias and mRNA folding strength synergize to boost protein production. Future work will investigate the molecular mechanisms of mRNA folding strength and its interaction with codon bias.
Broader Impacts
This project supported the training of a diverse group of 24 undergraduate students, 3 post-bac students, 5 graduate students, and 1 research assistant. These trainees learned technical skills in molecular and statistical genetics and cell biology as well as research ethics, project management, and science communication. The project also supported our engagement of local junior high school students with our Whatcom Wild Yeast Project. Students collected organic samples from their school or home environment and with our help, identified the species of yeast in their samples. In the process they learned about fungal biology, molecular biology, and the phylogenetic tree of life.
